#Text=Jim Hall ( computer programmer )
#Text=Jim Hall ( James F. Hall ) is a computer programmer and advocate of free software , best known for his work on FreeDOS .
#Text=Hall began writing the free replacement for the MS-DOS operating system in 1994 when he was still a physics student [ 1 ] at the University of Wisconsin-River Falls . [ 2 ]
#Text=He remains active with FreeDOS , and is currently the coordinator for the project . [ 3 ]
#Text=Hall has said he created FreeDOS in response to Microsoft announcing end of support for MS-DOS in 1994 , [ 1 ] a year before Windows 95 was released .
#Text=As a user and fan of MS-DOS , Hall did not want the functionality of DOS to go away .
#Text=Prompted by a March 31 , 1994 post on comp . os .
#Text=msdos . misc asking if " anyone , for example GNU et al. ever considered writing a Public Domain DOS " , [ 4 ]
#Text=Hall decided to garner support for a free version of DOS , written under a free or public domain model . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=In a June 29 , 1994 post , Hall announced an effort to create a free DOS , called PD-DOS , writing : [ 5 ]
#Text=A few months ago , I posted articles relating to starting a public domain version of DOS .
#Text=The general support for this at the time was ong , and many people agreed with the statement , " start writing ! "
#Text=So , I have …
#Text=Announcing the first effort to produce a PD-DOS .
#Text=I have written up a " manifest " describing the goals of such a project and an outline of the work , as well as a " task list " that shows exactly what needs to be written .

column1: #Text=I 'll post those here , and let discussion follow .
#Text=If you are thinking about developing , or have ideas or suggestions for PD-DOS , I would appreciate direct email to me .
#Text=If you just want to discuss the merits or morals of writing a PD-DOS , I 'll leave that to the net .
#Text=I 'll check in from time to time to see how the discussion is going , and maybe contribute a little to what promises to be a very polarized debate ! : ->
#Text=I am excited about PD-DOS , and I am hoping I can get a group started !
#Text=Within a few weeks , other programmers including Pat Villani and Tim Norman joined the project .
#Text=A kernel , the COMMAND . COM command line interpreter ( shell ) and core utilities were created by pooling code they had written or found available . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Hall wrote over a dozen of the first DOS utilities for the project , mostly file and batch utilities .

#Text=In a July 26 , 1994 post , Hall announced the PD-DOS project had been renamed to " Free-DOS " , having updated the project 's goals to intend to distribute source code under the GNU General Public License . [ 6 ]
#Text=The project would later be renamed " FreeDOS " , without the hyphen , after the publication of FreeDOS Kernel , by Pat Villani . [ 7 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Hall was the project 's release coordinator from Beta1 until about Beta7 , and also released the first alpha distribution of Free-DOS , as announced in a post on comp . os .
#Text=msdos . misc . [ 8 ]
#Text=He is again the project coordinator since April 2011 after Pat Villani 's departure .
#Text=Hall is also the original developer of GNU Robots , but he is no longer active on this project and has since handed maintainership over to Tim Northover .
#Text=It is now being developed by Bradley Smith .
